items.content_html: Pro Tip: The swift.org instructions for Linux installations arenâ€™t complete. Check out the bug report if youâ€™re getting a libpython error.
Taking my first crack at installing Swift on Linux. Been working to port my company website from sailsjs to Swift using Vapor. Itâ€™s quite nice so far.
Meetings, meetings, meetings. Today was full of meetings. But now the day is done and we go to the ocean tomorrow!
Finally also got a custom sub domain setup for my microblog, and am now mirroring micro posts to Github. Hooray for owning my own content ðŸŽ‰ðŸŽ‰ðŸŽ‰
I migrated my main blog to a new Ghost 1.0 server hosted on Linode last night. Digital Ocean is great but their $5 plan only has 512MB of RAM, where Linodeâ€™s has 1GB.

We stepped out of the house for a short couple of errands and missed the UPS delivery attempt of my new Kindle. They required a signature so we were greeted by a note on the door. I had no idea that they were going to require that on a $90 Kindle!
Holy moly the Xcode 9 refactor tool is great. I just renamed an entry in an NS_EXTENSIBLE_STRING_ENUM and it renamed the Swift uses as well as the Objective-C ones.
Ripping out Fabric feels pretty good. They seem to have cluttered up their UI a ton more than I would prefer. So Iâ€™m working on a new CloudKit analytics tool that I plan on open sourcing.

I tried setting up BuddyBuild for Scorebook. I have the RUN_CLANG_STATIC_ANALYZER set to Yes. The build fails becuase my Scorebook-Swift.h file doesnâ€™t get built. I turn it off, and the build works. Is this an Xcode bug?
Triggered segues in IBâ€™s storyboards seem like a good idea to get going quickly. But the reality is they can be a debugging nightmare. Glad I get to undo some of this old code.
